Award.AwardTitle: Pan American Advances Studies Institute on Scalable, Functional Nanomaterials; Costa Rica; June 2011
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Pan-American Advanced Studies Institutes (PASI) award, jointly supported by the NSF and the Department of Energy (DOE), will take place during June 2011 at the National Center for High Technology (CeNAT) in San Jose, Costa Rica. Organized by Dr. David Gracias of the John Hopkins University, the PASI will address research in scalable, functional nanomaterials with topics that range from self-assembly photonic and electronic materials to self-organizing DNA structures. The list of lecturers is extensive and harbors complementary research interests that will provide a broad overview of current efforts in nanomaterials science. Of clear relevance, careful thought has been given to what topics and materials can be translated into practice in countries that do not have extensive research budgets.
Scientific research on nanoscale phenomena has enlivened virtually all science and engineering disciplines over the last twenty years. The intended impact of the PASI is to bring a younger generation of scientists into contact with exciting areas of modern nanoscience that fit within the budget and facilities constraints of many middle income countries. Lectures are complemented with demonstrations, informal discussions and posters on student research. Recruiting targets include graduate students, and post-docs from throughout the Americas (North, Central and South). Moreover, students will become acquainted with successful scientists from a broad range of institutions and a wide range of countries. In addition, the PASI is expected to generate new collaborations throughout the Americas. Results from the PASI will be disseminated through websites for educational purposes with links, updates and presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant was used to organize and offset participation costs for graduate students, invited speakers and organizers from across the Americas at a symposium entitled, "Scalable, Functional Nanomaterials" that was held in Costa Rica. This symposium focused on the state of the art in nanomaterials with an emphasis on scalability and functionality.

The goal of the PASI was twofold: to bring together individuals from across the Americas in a way to foster information exchanges and collaborations, and to provide an introduction to scalable, functional nanomaterials. Since many of the countries in Central and South America have lower research funding levels and/or less developed scientific infrastructure than that of the United States, we have made an effort to select lecture topics based on nanomaterials that can be fabricated using inexpensive, bottom-up techniques and that require a relatively modest investment to initiate. This serves the dual purpose of presenting current nanomaterial research topics while also introducing topics that Central and South American countries, research centers, and universities could realistically investigate, given limited resources. Such lecture topics included: photonic materials, DNA self assembly, 3D nano-patterning and fabrication, electrospun polymer nanofibers, environmental applications of nanomaterials, nano-constructs for drug delivery, nano-infusion of polymers, and chemistry in nanopores.

We feel the goals of fostering collaboration were met and exceeded. In total we had 43 student participants hailing from the United States, Costa Rica, Puerto Rico, Mexico, Argentina, Chile, Venezuela, and Colombia. We also had 13 invited lecturers. The backgrounds of the lecturers varied quite widely and included expertise ranging from mechanical and electrical engineering, to chemistry, physics, and biology, to materials science. This level of expertise over such a broad range of topics is to be expected at a conference whose focus relates to scalable, functional nanomaterials, an area that demands multidisciplinary knowledge.

Activities at the PASI included 23 lectures, multiple students poster sessions (43 posters were submitted), hands-on demonstrations using an atomic force microscope, and two panel discussions focusing on career development and technical research.

A special effort was made to encourage participation from groups underrepresented in science and engineering. Additionally, to enhance graduate and post-doctoral education, student posters and interaction with leading academicians was encouraged.
